The tomb of national hero San Martin is guarded by two men in colourful uniform and around the outside there are many other small chapels and places for worship. However like so many Argentine memorial and treasures it is need of a little tender loving care. Plaster and paint have fallen from interior columns, many of the paintings could do with a clean and the interior is rather dark. It could be considerabaly better with a bit of attention. That aside, worth a visit. The peace and tranquility of the world is rudely shattered on leaving the cathedral however as it is sited alongside Plaza de Mayo, another busy area of traffic. Perhaps pedestrianising the road outside the cathedral would be the best option?

Misleading exterior.. What looks like a Greek temple from the outside, is in fact the Catholic Metropolitan Cathedral where the current Pope Francis was Cardinal Archbishop. Beautiful Gold alter area is well worth viewing.

A STRANGE BUILDING. From the outside it looks like it could be a bank or government offices- within it is totally Spanish Catholic with over the top gold / life size Jesus on a donkey & numerous clothed statues of the Virgin Mary. Two soldiers in Hollywood uniforms guard the burial place of General Sam Martin the liberator of Argentina from the Spanish rule. I did not feel the awe I feel when I enter the great European cathedrals. But it is certainly worth a visit within your trip to the Pink House/ Plaza de May etc.

Unusual Exterior, Large and Interesting Interior. The exterior is Greek Revival. The interior is a varied mix of styles influenced by various places in Europe.There is a lot of confusion among Trip Advisor reviews between this cathedral, Basilica del Santisimo, and San Pedro Gonzalez Telmo Church. The Catedral Metropolitana is in the Plaza de Mayo which you will likely visit anyway, and the Greek Revival exterior is different from the other churches close by.This is interesting to see although I would not rate it as one of my favorite churches by a long shot. It is free. Worth an hour, and if you can do it with a local guide all the better.If this review is helpful then please indicate so below.

Shockingly Different Inside from Outside. The outside is a Greek Revival style with an interesting frieze showing what looks like a confrontation between Moses and Pharaoh. Inside, it's a mix of different European-influenced styles. Not the most stunning cathedral I've ever seen, nor something to plan your trip around, but it's free and in Plaza de Mayo which you should visit anyways. Plus it's free.
Greek Cathedral. On the inside it is a classic Catholic cathedral, on the outside it is an ancient Greek temple. Strange but true.

Meeting with the spiritual heart of the city. Although the outside is not that appealing as the churches in, let's say Europe, the inside is quite different. Very well preserved and interesting enough to know this was the place where the current Pope used to work. I went twice. The second and last time was a Sunday to attend a mass. The choir left me speechless... Try to attend a mass even if you are not Catholic.

Another cathedral...how many can you visit in BA?. It's a whacking great cathedral and the centrepiece has to be the backdrop and surrounds of the altar that appears to be made from solid gold. Lighting is not good inside and photography isn't easy but it's quite a stunning sight.Various side altars/chapels and packed with tourists. Worth a quick visit

Imposing. Like all great Cathedrals it has an atmosphere. The Art,,chapel alters, statues and architecture add to this. The Pope is pictured and revered at the entrance. Many pilgrims were in attendance the day we visited and it seemed irreverent to dwell in this special place too long

Visit to Catedral Metropolitana. Four tourists from a cruise ship visited Plaza de Mayo. This was a very beautiful plaza that had the Catedral Metroplitana right across the street from the plaza. This was a very beautiful cathedral that was the home cathedral for Pope Francis. We were very glad that we got to tour this cathedral. This is a beautiful cathedral is definitely a must see.

A must. We were there on a sunday, there was a celebration, at the end of the mass the priest walked down the aisle and waited for the people and shook the hand of the people respectfully.This is a beautiful church definitely a must see.

Interesting folk art. Arriving at plaza de Mayo, I came upon a building that looks on the outside like an attempt to replicate the Parthenon. Inside, one sees beautiful stained glass windows, an ornate alter, fairly good oil paintings depicting the life of Christ (with emphasis on the crucifiction), an armed guard whose swords dissuade one from defacing the rather large tomb of the first governor of modern Argentina, now beatified (although I saw nobody praying to him), perhaps for being one of those 'good' politicians. In one alcove there is a life-sized model of Jesus riding a donkey, something I have not seen in a cathedral apart from Christmastime. Several alcoves have small dolls representing Mary and dressed in elaborate dolls clothes. Again something unusual from my limited experience. A nice side chapel was separated by large curtains, allowing the three occupants to pray in relative privacy this Sunday, while tourists like myself paraded through the main part.

Unusual Cathedral. When viewed from the outside this looks more like an old city government building with huge baroque columns. Inside is a lovely church that houses the tomb of General Jose' de San Martin, Argentina's most revered hero. There are tours in Spanish but not in English. It is still an active church with many masses.
Gorgeous Church. Situated Its a very gorgeous church having this very golden look all around. Was very impressive of the architecture and the several statues around it.

Impressive. The Metropolitan Cathedral is situated around the main city-square. Inside the Cathedral, the architecture and several statues are quite impressive. We happened to be visiting on a Sunday and therefore, were able to witness the solemn religious service.
Gorgeous. Neither you're catholic or not, you should visit Buenos Aires Cathedral. It is an awesome construction and a inspiring place to keep your thoughts in peace.

A beautiful place. You walk up the steps and once inside you are struck by the beauty and splendour of the cathedral. Calm and quiet just as you would hope it would be.An emphasis on Pope Francis, as you would expect; such pride in the city, it is difficult not to be swept along with the atmosphere.A lovely calm moment in a busy city.

Christmas Eve Service. We came for the much-mentioned Christmas Eve service, and it was lovely. I did wish I knew more Spanish so I could have followed along better, but it was still quite atmospheric. It's not the most splashy cathedral in the world, but it's pretty and gets the job done.

San Martin's tomb. Very large and spacious with lovely architecture - particularly the vaulted ceilings. Loved the stories attached to most of the side altars, especially the jewish connection. Disliked the huge number of big groups being shown around by overly loud guides.

Learn some history from this Cathedral. From the outside the architecture doesn’t look anything like a cathedral. It has no bell tower, just like any historical building. It has been rebuilt and renovated a few times. Now the cathedral is mixed with 18th century dome and 19th century facade. The interior has 18th century precious statues and altar pieces, and Renaissance decorations. The big attraction inside is Mausoleum of General San Martin. He was a Spanish captain that helped Argentina, Chile, and Peru gain independence from the Spanish in the early part of the 19th century.At the Mausoleum they have 2 soldiers standing guard. I learned some history from this visit. Happy Travelling!

MY #2 FAVORITE ATTRACTION IN BUENOS AIRES!. Next to Teatro Colon, my #2 favorite attraction in Buenos Aires, Argentina is the Cathedral Metropolitana. It's more beautiful and bigger than the one in Santiago, Chile which has the same name. There are several alcoves or altars inside this Cathedral, each one depicting different saints. I like the intricacies of the art works of these alcoves, walls and ceilings. Tomb of General Martin - two guards stand alert next to this tomb. This General helped liberate Argentina from Spain. I think he did the same thing in other countries such as Peru (saw his statutes in Lima, Peru).Other attractions near by: Cabildo, Parque de Mayo, and Casa Rosada.I said my prayers before leaving this beautiful Cathedral. Hope you enjoy your visit of this place and related attractions.

Pope's church. Viewed from the outside it looks like an official building ,maybe a library. Inside it is pure Catholic Cathedral. This as you probably know is Pope Francis's parish. It also includes the burial site of San Martin. Interesting to walk through with a guide as the history is not apparent

Unassuming outside, impressive inside. Could be mistaken for a bank on the outside, but very impressive on the inside. Jose de Martin, Argentina's liberator, is entombed inside, complete with classically dressed uniformed guards at the entrance.

The Pope's Parish. I'm not a Catholic, so I'll get the terminology wrong. This was the "home base" for the current Pope when he was Archbishop of Buenos Aires. Beyond that, it is a very interesting mix of styles and construction reflecting several periods of construction, renovation and modification. A surprise was the tomb of Argentine liberator Jose de San Martin with an honor guard of Argentine soldiers in full ceremonial dress uniform. Their changing of the guard ceremony is low key, but very impressive, and the guard detail then marches out of the the cathedral and down the street to the "Pink House" about 500 meters away.

The best they have. This low-rise neo-classical structure, with its massive pillars and triangular facade busy with stone carvings, and topped with a very modest cupola, began in the 16th Cent., but not all that well, because it had to go through several reincarnations most of which were a result of poor design or bad craftsmanship in its earlier phases. It occupies a prime site at one corner of Plaza de Mayo, and as the major ecclesiastical building of the city it seems like a massive understatement. The interior is more in line with its status, with lots of religious flourishes such as a Stations of the Cross executed by local artists, and two unusual statues of the Saviour: Christ of Buenos Aires, and Christ of Great Wealth. A little more wealth is needed, as several areas are not in good repair, with peeling surfaces and eroded plaster and brickwork. Most of the available money seems to go to the maintenance of the Cathedral's showpiece, the Mausoleum of General San Martin and two of his senior military associates who, together with Bolivar, brought about the independence of the continent. Apart from the florid architecture, sculpture, the high-raised pedestal with the great soldier lying flat on his back and draped with a shroud, and the Roman style multi-concentric decorated dome, there are plaques of appreciation from several other countries to whose liberation San Martin contributed. A nice democratic touch is that the Unknown Soldier of Independence is also buried with his superiors. Two live soldiers are permanently on guard. The cathedral boasts an enormous organ of 3,500 individual pipes that is worth a look, although I did not hear it play. The final sight that struck a chord with me is a small chapel ----- the first on the left as you enter, that holds a celebrated icon ----- a small framed portable representation of the Virgin called Our Lady of Lujan --------- that San Martin carried with him into battle, with gratifying results. On the left wall of the same chapel, almost as a non-sequitur as I cannot see the relationship, you will find a memorial to the Holocaust, and plaques describing the 200,000 survivors who made their homes in Argentina.
Nice Cathedral. If for no other reason, go visit this church for the tomb of Argentina liberator Jose de San Martin.

Beautiful place to visit and contemplative. Seing it from outside, I did not realize it is a church , rather I thought it's a museum, by far I didn't expect it is the Cathedral. But after stepping in I was overwhelmed by the architecture and style. It's a "Must See" in B.A.

Christmas Eve. I was surprised at the low-key architecture, especially as this cathedral is right by La Casa Rosada and Cabildo de Buenos Aires. Inside, the traditional catholic chapels were well used and beautiful. I enjoyed the visit
Very pretty. We stumbled upon the Catedral in downtown BA, and it was magnificent. The high ceilings blew us away, and you could tell there was so much history in the place.

Beautiful Church. We arrived at the Catedral Metropolitana mid morning and got a treat with a children's choir doing their Christmas concert. The church has beautiful architecture. We were told that Pope Francis spent a number of years at this cathedral--that made it even more special.

Hmmm. Kind of strange to find a Roman-style building housing a cathedral in South America. Perhaps it reflects that many Argentinians' origins are Italian? Didn't do much for me but if you're in the area.....

if you happen to be there.... ...you may pay the Cathedral a visit. we didn't find it that intersting but, since it's one of the historic icons of the city, it added value to our visit to that area. i personally preferred the Convento de Santo Domingo, Belgrano Ave 'n Defensa, which is 5/6 blocks away from the cathedral and its history is much more interesting. If you happen to go on a weekend, you may then walk along the Defensa St and enjoy street art sales, local crafts, have a pizza at the Continental or have luch at Esteban de Luca, go to El Mercado de las Pulgas and get some bargain
Lovely Church. The exterior of this church is not a good indicator of what you will find inside. Very lovely and ornate inside. Located right on the Plaza de Mayo.

beautiful!. The cathedral has a Roman-Greek style facade. But inside it's dark and very ornate.In addition, it holds the rests of General San Martin, Argentina's "Libertador" (liberator). The location is great since Casa Rosada and Cabildo are near, as well as Plaza de Mayo.

Don't be deceived by the exterior. The exterior gives you no idea of what to expect when you step inside, although to be fair the external frieze is a sight in itself.
The tomb of General Jose de San Martin is very impressive with a couple of soldiers in full dress uniform on guard. The altar is standard RC fare as are the side chapels.

great catedral. Not a gothic nor roman one but a very modern from XIX century.
Inside is the monument to some of the great heroe of argentina history.
catedral is near the cabildo and casa rosada

The exterior fools you. Having visited a large variety of cathedrals in Europe and parts of Latin America, I was quite fooled by the exterior, expecting to find a more modern decor. Step inside and you will find much like what you can find in cathedrals around the world: dark, very ornate, lots of iron bars. Highlights include the connection with Pope Francis and the mausoleum of San Martín. You don't need to spend much time here, and fortunately it is located on the north side of the Plaza de Mayo.

Not your standard cathedral. Usually a Latin American cathedral has broad steps, two towers, and could just as easily be set in Spain. This one is in classic style, Roman or Greek, and it speaks, I believe, to the more diverse backgrounds of the populace, and to the pretensions of the proud Portenos. That being said, I found it gloomy.

Very nice to visit, close to Casa Rosada . It's an old and nice church, with a nice religious atmosphere and the mausoleum of General San Martin, a very notorious character in Argentinian history. If we'd have to drive for hours to reach it I'd be a little disappointed. But it's close to the Casa Rosada and Plaza de Mayo, so it really felt good to visit. If you're lucky enough there were some church organ concerts scheduled.
Normal church. The cathedral is like most churches. There is nothing special about it. The facade is different and it does not look like a church.

Nice Cathedral, with a strong historical identity. This Cathedral is an Iconic place in the traditional centre of Buenos Aires, is next to Plaza de Mayo Square. It's a Building related to Greek-roman Architecture. In the Cathedral you will find the "General San Martin Mausoleo". That's the place where the remains of General San Martin are.

General San Martin at the Catedral. General San Martin Mausoleo....if you want to know about the héroe of Argentina...please visit the Cathedral...and feel the power of the most important General of Argentina, who give freedom to Argentina, Peru , Chile, ....a real Heroe

Mixed architectural styles. Others call it bland, as we went past several times, thought we were looking at a Grecian style building - hard to say what it is but eventually realise it is a cathedral that is so different on the inside.

Beautiful and sublime. . Went there for Sunday mass during our 8 dat stay. The building itself is beautiful and the icons and paintings culturally and aesthetically sublime. One learns a lot about a culture when experiencjng the way religion is expressed.

Plain Outside: Gorgeous Inside. This simple, though large buidling wouldn't draw attention unless you were paying attention. From the outside it doesn't look at all like a Catholic cathedral. But go inside, and you'll be swept away by the beautiful church, altar, inlaid floors, and statuary. It also houses the guarded tomb of Juan San Martin, liberator of Argentia. Be sure to see the touching Holocaust "exbit" on the left side of the church. I particularly loved the small statue of Michael the Archangel on the right side in back.

A beautiful hidden cathedral!. The Cathedral doesn't look anything like you'd imagine from the outside, I sort of rambled in there by mistake but I was happy I did! The architecture inside the church is beautiful and it's very relaxing taking a short walk inside. There are many different types of catholic idols that are worth going to see.Visited August 2013

Home of Pope Francis. Located steps from the Presidential Palace, but difficult to identify initially because it doesn't look like a church from the outside, but more like a bank or courthouse. Highlight for me was the mausoleum of General San Martin, complete with two honour guards. There is no admission fee and photos are allowed. Hours: M-F 7:30am-6:45pm, weekends 9am-7pm.
Very beautiful. Historic place. The architecture is very amazing and its a good place to relax and Thanks God for all..

Looks like a bank on the outside. We didn't find it the first time we visited the Plaza de Mayo because it doesn't look like a church on the outside. Certainly does on the inside. We were lucky to be there during organ practice - beautiful music filling a large and attractive worship space.

Highlight of Buenos Aires. Absolutely gorgeous cathedral near Casa Rosada. The construction, paintings and altars are out of this world and it amazes by the demonstrations of faith by the locals. The place where San Martin is buried is also very busy. To me it was one of the best visits in Buenos Aires

Beautiful old cathedral. The building looks bland from the outside, but the inside was just the opposite.While you're there, ensure you visit General Jose de San Martin’s tomb which is flanked by a couple of guards. We just missed the Change of Guards unfortunately.Cameras are allowed.Worth a visit!

Cathedral Metropolitana, Buenos Aires. The simple architectural lines of the exterior don't prepare you for the opulence on the interior. Very restful and a beautiful providing a break from the hectic city surrounding it. We admired the decorative arches, altars and stunning stained glass windows; and were fortunate to do so while a mass was being held in a small chapel off to one side which added to the sedate atmosphere.

In the Footsteps of Pope Francis. Buenos Aries is a fantastic city. It was a privilege to be able to visit this Cathedral, the home of the first Latin American Pope. The building looks nothing like a standard cathedral from the outside which was deliberate as it was designed to blend into the civil society of Argentina. Inside there are many interesting things to see from the passionflowers in the floor mosaics to the tomb of the founder of independent Argentina complete with national guards. If you get a chance the simple crypt is worth a visit to sit in quiet contemplation

Understated facade, impressive interior. This is the former church of Pope Francis, and one is tempted to say that like him it is outwardly modest (well, it does have a few columns and a tympanum giving it the appearance of a Greek temple more than of a Christian church, but now towering steeples or such like) but pretty impressive when you get to know it. Plenty of elaborate altars and statuary inside, including a monument to San Martín, Argentina's national hero.

ASuprise Inside!!. Although it has a generic neoclassic facade that almost makes it look like a government building, visitors to the Metropolitan Cathedral will be very pleased once they enter. The interior is cool, beautiful and harmonious. Many reviewers write about the impressive tomb for San Martin as well as the tomb of the unknown soldier. I was moved by the chapel that contained remembrances for victims of 20th century genocides. There is a plaque commemorating Armenians and there are framed prayer book pages from the WWII concentration camps, the Berlin Synagogue and material that survived the early 90's terrorist bombings of the Israeli Embassy and Jewish Center in Argentina. That such a memorial was in the Buenos Aires Cathedral filled us with emotion and admiration for the city.

Watch out for the "pigeon poop" pick pockets near the Cathedral!. My experience near the Cathedral spoiled my entire week in BsAs, and I would never stay in the city again in consequence. The Cathedal, Plaza de Mayo, and area near the Cathedral has a concentration of those pickpockets who throw "pigeon poop" on tourists. They work in pairs.Here's what happened to us, although similar stories are told by others. To get to the area my husband and I took the Blue Subte line, and got out at Peru station (because they had closed access to the Catedral station, for what reason we didn't know at the time). This meant that we had to walk on the streets near the Cathedral, near entrances to the Subte, and Plaza de Mayo. Two middle aged ladies, well dressed so you would never suspect them, were standing nearby as I looked dow into the Subte entrance and saw it was barricaded. Suddenly I felt wet runny liquid "goop" all over my hair, clothes and bag I was carrying, which came from behind me. It was dripping down my forehead, and I could hardly see because my glasses were covered with it. There was a lot of it - perhaps as much as half a litre! I turned and could sort of see one of the women pointing at the sky, as if to indicate a bird, and the other one had pulled out a kleenex tissue and was approaching me, looking concerned and waving the tissue back and forth, as if she would wipe it off. Of course there was far more quasi "pigeon poop" than could be caused by one bird. And I had read about this pickpocket method, so I immediately moved away from both of them, didn't let them touch me or my bag, and waved my cane threateningly as if to strike them. My husband came toward us, and they ran away. So I didn't lose anything.The worst was that there was a policewoman right nearby who did nothing! When I returned to the hotel I was told my the staff that it likely was because the police see this all the time so they don't bother. The grey stinky stuff was so vile I had to go back to the hotel and take an entire shower, and start washing everything. This wasted an entire morning and was very unpleasant. The stains would not come out of my clothes when I tried to wash them. I had to throw that bag away. The stench still lingered in my bag contents for the entire rest of the trip, although I washed them and tried to get rid of it .  I posted about my experience on one of the Buenos Aires forums before, but think that I should mention this again here. Tourists, most of whom at some point visit the main Buenos Aries downtown Cathedral, should know what is going on in that area. If this happens to you, don't let them near you because in the process of "cleaning you up" they will steal your belongings. My husband now refers to these as Poop-edores, because they are worse than pushy obnoxious vendedores.

A place of peace. . This is not the most beautiful of cathedrals but it does have a sense of peace amid the hurly burly of life. For me the Bishops Chair said it all. - humble and simple - unlike so many cathedral furnishings. Say a prayer for the people of this wonderful country that lives on the edge of the world.

One of the most beautiful Cathedrals in the city. Over the years I have visited this Cathedral on many occassions. It is close to Plaza de Mayo and Casa Rosada in the micro centro. The architecture and design is beautiful and if you have some time, admire the inside of the church. Here you will find the mausoleum of General Jose de San Martin. There is a memorial inside the church for Jewish victims of WWII behind the altar. Definitely recommended when in Buenos Aires.

The light for Argentina never goes out. A lamp shines outside for the eternal life of the country. And inside is an incredible statesmanly tribute to General Jose Martin draped dramatically in the blue and white flag and guarded by two smartly turned out guards with guns. Freedom under protection.

Surprises Lie Inside. Surprise number 1 is the mausoleum of General Jose de San Martin, the hero of Argentine independence from Spain. It's to the right of the nave. Surprise number 2 is a memorial dedicated to Argentina's large Jewish community. It contains documents found in the death camps of Auschwitz, the ruins of Berlin’s synagogue and the remains of this city’s Jewish community center, which was bombed in 1994 by Iran's Hezbollah. Rather remarkable that this memorial is inside Argentina's national cathedral.

The bland exterior hides the treasure inside. On the same square, Plaza de Mayo, as Casa Rosda the Catedral Meropolitana offers a great opportunity for a quick, accessible visit to an important chruch in Argentina. And it is free.The Cathedral has an impressive altar and also houses the tomb of General San Martin - He led Argentina in a battle for independence against the Spanish Empire.It's a busy church and there are many serivices going on here.

The tomb. Stunning interior and it also contains the tomb of Gen San Martin that is guarded by two permanent soldiers. A very historic building. Not such a good looking building from the outside though. Well worth a visit.

Plain exterior hides a glorious interior. With the choice of Pope Francis, this cathedral takes on even greater importance. Though the exterior has a rather unassuming appearance, once inside, the cathedral exudes an uncommon warmth, fronted by a very lovely altar. We were most fortunate that the timing of our visit coincided with an organ recital. The whole experience had a wonderful, otherworldly feel. On such a hot November day, this was a cool and refreshing respite.

Worth a visit. Visited this cathedral whilst mass was taking place and must admit that all visitors were respectful of this and were quite and unobtrusive. Visited it again and witnessed changing of the guard at the general's tomb. all in all an impressive cathedral and it is well maintained inside. stunning statues and architecture. The mausoleum is worth a visit and you are free to take photographs of the guards as well. Great historical importance. Enjoyed visits and it is welcome to get into the cool after the Argentinian sun!! Great for tourists and locals who are very proud of their heritage,

Plaza de Mayo Jewel. With history dating back to the 1500s, I was definitely pumped to visit this cathedral. A bonus is that it included an important gravesite as well as the country's tomb of the Unknown Soldier. I stumbled out of the hot Buenos Aires sun after visiting the Casa Rosado into the cool interior of this cathedral under the Classical portico.I felt as if I had been transported to Europe. I almost forgot I was in Argentina - and it is landmarks like this cathedral that have given BA the sobriquet of Paris of South America. The nave is pretty symmetrical with clean lines and rich moulding. Even though most of the architecture is from different periods - Rococo to Classical to Neoclassical - the image as a whole is unified and pleasant. I happened to visit in-between services; however I would take a guess that the acoustics would be excellent. The altar was impressive and massive. I especially liked the dome and the high windows - enough light made the interior feel heavenly. Of course, the tomb of General San Martin was breath-taking. A black marble sarcophagus, flanked by statues of Argentina, Peru, and Chile, guarded by the members of the Argentinian military is one I will not forget. Nearby are the remains of Generals Juan Gregorio de las Heras and Tomas Guido, as well as an unknown soldier of the Independence War.The cathedral is free to visit and photograph. I respectfully encourage a small donation for upkeep of the building, though. Touring this site is the perfect way to have a reprieve from the Argentinian sun and see a historical treasure.
Cathedral in Plaza de Mayo. The exterior was under renovation. Inside was crowded with tourists and noisy school children. Graceful arches in the nave.

A Cathedral with two pluses!. The current cathedral was built on the place reserved for the major church of the town when Juan de Garay founded Buenos Aires in 1580 and on a series of previous churches that had occupied the site, something which is common in Latin America. Some think that the Cathedral’s exterior appearance (of official looking) seems to be a bank, government offices or something of the sort at first sight. There are some “architectural” reasons: its Neoclassical façade, the tall portico, (inspired by Classical architecture) and its 12 columns make the church look more like an ancient temple. However, the decoration of the façade representing Joseph’s meeting with his brothers and father Jacob in Egypt, and intending to provide an allegory of the unity of the Argentine nation, clearly speaks of a religious place. On the other hand, the 12 Corinthian capitals of the columns of the portico symbolize the 12 apostles.  In the interior, you can feel a European flavour (as in many parts in Buenos Aires, indeed). Abundant Neo-Renaissance and Neo-Baroque decoration; the floor is stunning. Pay attention to it. All the usual beautiful work you would expect in a cathedral. But there is a plus: San Martin, our national hero, the Father of the country, is buried here. Don’t miss his resting place. This gorgeous mausoleum has Guard of Honour (worthwhile seeing it changing). These colonial era-dressed soldiers are always willing to have a photo taken and even posing with visitors. So, don’t be shy and ask for a pic!A brief note: San Martin died in France, but in 1880 his remains were brought and placed in the black sarcophagus one can see nowadays. He is surrounded by 3 life-size female figures representing the 3 countries he freed: Argentina, Chile and Peru. Two other Great Men’s remains are there as well: those of Generals Juan Gregorio de las Heras and Tomás Guido. Finally, the Unknown Soldier of the Independence’s tomb is there too.It is right that it has nothing out of the ordinary; that it only offers pretty much what one would expect from a cathedral. But a detail makes it different from others: Pope Francisco used to hold mass here!  Free entrance. Photos: allowed (both flash and non-flash). However, it is a good idea to be respectful of faith followers and to avoid being camera happy during the service.

Exterior is more like an ancient temple..... Most capitol cities around the world invariably has a Cathedral belonging to one or more religious denominations - BA has the Metropolitan and it belongs to the Catholic Diocese.It has a striking exterior in a plain colour with a magnificent façade - an intricate frieze of sculptures above twelve columns. It’s interesting to note that it has been rebuilt without any towers and it reminds me of some ancient Mediterranean temple.Once inside we immediately noticed the soaring height of the roof and the intricate tile walkways and floors.It’s not as ornate as some South American churches but still has a baroque style and a gorgeous rococo alter. Look for the unique statue of Christ carved from the wood of an algarrobo or carob tree.The layout is in the shape of a Latin cross with transept, three-aisles and side chapels connected by high arches.One of BA’s earlier liberators is interred in a mausoleum here - General José de San Martín and an eternal flame burns for him outside the church. If you are here at the right time you may witness a guard ceremony however even without this showy spectacle the church is well worth a visit - not too much of the favoured gold leaf detail on every square inch! It’s very close to Plaza de Mayo and within easy reach in the city centre.Enjoy your experience!

A slice of history. Here again a guide was ideal in showing me the church highlights and burial site of liberator Jose de San Martin .Most unusual- there is a holocaust memorial in the church - wonder if its the only church in the world where is a holocaust memorial

If at Plaza de Mayo, go . . .. Is this the most magnificent cathedral in the world? No. Still, it's worth seeing for a few reasons:1. It was built over and over before this final version persevered, so it's interesting from the standpoint of the Argentinian version of a national cathedral; 2. Pope Francis has a history here; 3. it is free and right there at the edge of Plaza de Mayo, which makes it easy to locate and visit. Again, while it has some nice features and art, the fact that it is not over-the-top in decoration and style is a comment on the country and its relationship to God.My favorite thing related to this cathedral was that we were walking to Plaza de Mayo one Sunday afternoon and came upon a mass of people outside who were listing to a sermon in the closed-off area in front of the cathedral. The passion of some of the crowd was amazing. There was a screened facade erected on the front to hide construction being done when we were there.

Feel ease and warm at Sunday mass!. We walked in and joined the Sunday mass as it was in progress. Afterward the Bishop greeted and chatted with folks after the mass. Just like any Sunday mass. However, it carries a lot of historical national significance, but also reflects Pope Francisco style and value.

Not your typical cathedral. I have been to many cathedrals around the world and this one looks like a town hall from the outside. There are no spires or other structures piercing the sky. There are 12 pillars outside which make it look very business like. On top of that, when I went early May 2013, there is quite a bit of scaffolding outside; obvious repair work going on. Inside is totally different with large Christian icons and paintings. I have seen better Catholic Cathedrals than this one though. What made me feel good is that the new Pope Francisco, used to hold mass here! I have included one picture of the inside of the cathedral and another one from Avenue 9 de Julio where there is a massive banner across a large office block showing off that the new Pope is from Buenos Aires.
Very nice. A place any tourist must visit. Specially with the nomination on Pope Francisco. Historical place of many events.

Worth a look.. The outside looks more like a bank to me. The inside is another story. While relatively austere compared to other Catholic churches in other big cities, the decor impresses nevertheless.
Worth a visit. It is definitely worth visiting this Cathedral if you happen to be in the area. The building looks plain from the outside but the art work inside is something worth seeing.

Beautiful Cathedral and San Martin's final Resting Place. Accidentally showed up during Sunday services and was able to get in and take pictures (both flash and non-flash, but not of the service or parishioners). Viewed all the glorious religious artwork and paintings. My highlight was the Mausoleum of General San Martin.

Simple outside, beautiful inside. There's a long wait for the shop but the rest of this building is spectacular. There's not much holy water around though so I gather the tourists have been scooping it up since pope Francis.

Worth a visit to see San Martin's tomb. I'm not an expert in religious sites, but having visited many cathedrals in Europe there really wasn't anything awe-inspiring to see. The entrance is free, so that's a plus, and for anyone interested in South American history the tomb of General San Martin makes it worthwhile to come in for a short visit.

Hidden gem. It looked like a bank but inside was a tranquil space in busy Buenos Aires. There are many small chapels, San Martin's mausoleum, an honour guard ( changes around 3:30) for San Martin, a meditative space and a peaceful feeling that we enjoyed as we sat and reflected. The floors are beautiful and seem to made by the same craftsmen as the opera house. All the usual beautiful work you would expect in a cathedral, but it was the calming atmosphere that I appreciated the most as the outside noise, protesters, traffic, etc fell away. I think you might be able to hear some music in here but not during our visit. I enjoyed that they are honouring San Martin but it is on the outside edge because he had become a Freemason. And it's free!

18th Century Cathedral of distinction. General Jose de San Martin is buried here.He liberated Argentina from Spain. The stained glass windows are excellent and the serenity of this cathedral is something special. Its vast expanse is to be enjoyed

Nothing out of the ordinary- but worth a visit if you're in the area- plus it's free. As far as cathedrals go you can throw this one on the pile if you've been to cathedrals anywhere else in South America or Europe . That being said it is a nice quiet respite for the bustling city outside. Fairly well restores its a short walk to make your way around and it is nice to see locals pop in and out throughout the day. Nothing exceptional, but its convenient and free so it wouldn't hurt to stop by if you're in the area.
Pretty much what one would expect from a cathedral. It's a nice cathedral in an urban area. Nothing special in my opinion, but worth going if you're already there to Plaza Mayo, Casa Rosada, etc.

Buenos Aires's remarkably restrained cathedral. The cathedral is the Greek temple styled building on the same square as the Casa Rosada. It's remarkably smaller and more restrained than one would think of a city where thy liked to build BIG. However, inside it is comforting and built on a human scale - with 2 key features of interest (1) the tomb of General San Martin - who liberated both Chile and Argentina from the Spanish - which is girded by two smart colonial era-dressed soldiers who are happy to pose for photographs, and (2) the altar and pulpit etc - made from repousse silver - tons of silver. Serious bling!

Pleasantly surprising cathedral in Buenos Aires downtown!. From a distance, Cathedral Metropolitana's front facade, architecture may resemble a gov building or small museum... or like a Parthenon look-alike. But it is different inside. Not a towering height but it retains classic cross pattern, deceptively grand upper windows, mosaics & beautiful paintings inside. Another surprise is the live guards on hand to protect the St. Martins honored tomb inside the cathedral. Very worthwhile visit even though some of us may think of tall stretching gothic spyres, this is just as authentic, inside. I enjoyed the Sunday morning mass yesterday, very spiritually touched. My only negative point is that I wish the visiting bus crowds would be more respectful, more quiet & less camera happy during the mass.

Beautifully detailed church. One would think its a bank or governments offices, but inside is grand church, with lots of shrines and the tomb of a General inside, was quite impressed by the scale and grandeur of it all.

Catholic cathedral. Despite the exterior appearance, this official looking building is in fact the main Catholic cathedral. It is enormous inside and very much a tourist hotspot both for foreigners and Argentinian school children. They are there not only to view the cathedral but also the Mausoleum of General San Martín. He has his own guard of honour - the changing of which is worth seeing. Behind curtains, on the right hand side of the main alter is a small side chapel which is worth a look for the alter - and also the place for quiet prayer & contemplation. Check out the organ - apparently made in Germany with 3500 tubes. We went to a free recital as advertised on a list by the cathedral entrance doors.

Historical Buenos Aires. The exterior of this cathedral is unwelcoming. The interior has a rich European flavor. The tomb of San Martin is located outside the walls of the cathedral because he became a Freemason before he died.The floor is stunning. The colors are beautiful. The individual chapels are interesting but not as much as those in European cathedrals.We did encounter a pickpocket so be careful.

Don't judge a book by its cover!. We stopped in front of the cathedral on a walking tour. Our guide asked us to guess what this building could be---a court house, the treasury, a mausoleum? No one guessed a Catholic church! We later went back to see the cathedral's interior. Quite beautiful. I was especially taken with the Via Crucis (Stations of the Cross) paintings by Italian painter Francesco Domenighini. Also take note of the mosaic floor. The changing of the guard at San Martin's tomb was impressive. There's also a very small gift shop where we purchased a few small items.

Cathedral. I had no idea this was a cathedral. The outside looks more like a courthouse or government building, but when I went inside, I was surprised to see that this was a church! The inside was beautiful and had many displays and paintings of religious figures as well as important political people. General San Martin's Mausoleum is here and is really neat to see. I'm not religious at all, but I could appreciate the beauty inside and the craftmanship of the architecture.

It hardly looks like a Cathedral on the outside, but.... ...it is! A good one too, with fine services. A quick look around is certainly in order, not least to behold South America's liberating hero, San Martin. The honorary guard and the sarcophagus are worth the visit by themselves.

Cathedral. It has the standards of every other Capital City Cathedral, mixture of greek and local colonial style, plus some historical focal-points like national hero San Martin's tomb. I suggest attending a Mass on some high date so to experience one of its Organs in action.

A HELTER SKELTER BUILDING. The main Catholic church of Buenos Aires is a mix of architectural styles and lacks the majesty of other temples of its category. Its final construction started by the mid 1700's and was finished in the 19th Century. Of interest are the collection of flags and the tomb of General San Martín.
Nice Greek Churc. It's our most importante Catholic Church. Built in a greek style. Inside you are going to find San Martin's tomb, our national heroe

Colonial Cathedral. Buenos Aires Cathedral is not too impressive compared to other Argentine Colonial churches, but it holds the remains of San Martín, our national hero who liberated Argentina, Chile and Peru between 1812 and 1821. A cathedral has stood on this site since 1580. On Plaza de Mayo central square
Okay Cathedral. Nothing wrong, just nothing spectacular, though I was impressed by San Martin's tomb plus honor guard. This is,essentially, a minor site.

Visiting the national cathedral of Argentina. I visited the Cathedral Metropolitana on two occasions during my first weekend in Buenos Aires, the first by myself and the second with a private tour guide. The latter visit added immensely to my knowledge of the building.The cathedral is situated on the edge of the Plaza de Mayo and impossible to miss. Entrance is free. There appears to be masses held on a daily basis but you are freely allowed entrance into the building during these times. The crypt of San Martin (roughly the equivalent of George Washington for Argentines) is to the right of the entrance and the reason why most probably stop by. Suspiciously reminiscent of Napoleon's tomb in Paris, it is definitely worth a visit. To the left of the nave, there is a memorial to the Jewish community from the Catholic church containing sheets of prayers rescued from the ruins of Auschwitz and Treblinka.Initially the church was a bit of a challenge because I am not fluent in Spanish and there are no English subtitles on the placards, nor is a map of the facility or audio guide available. Traveling with a native guide made up for these issues immensely. Recommended.

floor plan information. need the floor plans of the cathedral metropolitana for a college architech course any information of obtaining this information or where i can look would be greatly appreciated thank you
